value.title: Corydon: Five arrests after Met Police uses live facial recognition
value.excerpt: The Metropolitan Police has arrested five people after using Live Facial Recognition (LFR) technology in south London. The force said it deployed the technology in Croydon on 19 January as part of its work to "reduce serious violence". Civil liberties organisation Liberty called the Met's use of the technology "deeply concerning".

value.title: Humans still cheaper than AI in vast majority of jobs, MIT study finds
value.excerpt: Artificial intelligence can’t replace the majority of jobs right now in cost-effective ways, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology found in a study that sought to address fears about AI replacing humans in a swath of industries.

value.title: Cops Used DNA to Predict a Suspect’s Face—and Tried to Run Facial Recognition on It
value.excerpt: Leaked records reveal what appears to be the first known instance of a police department attempting to use facial recognition on a face generated from crime-scene DNA. It likely won’t be the last.

value.title: 3 Ways Generative AI Is Making Our World A Better Place
value.excerpt: Discover three inspiring examples of how generative AI is positively transforming our world: from preserving the Icelandic language to making literature more accessible.

value.title: Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg to be deposed in Texas facial recognition case

value.title: Facial recognition could play key role in workplace safety for football players
value.excerpt: A survey of football player unions found that fan violence is a growing concern, and tech interventions like facial recognition could help keep players safe.

value.title: Sam’s Club Deploys AI-Powered Computer Vision to Speed Payment Confirmation
value.excerpt: Sam’s Club is piloting tech designed to address a big customer pain point: waiting for an associate to check their receipt against the items in their cart.

value.title: Sam’s Club is testing out AI, computer vision tech to speed up exit process at stores
value.excerpt: Pilots are currently underway at 10 Sam’s Club locations and involves a combination of computer vision and digital technology which captures images of carts and verifies payment for all the items in the shopper’s possession.

value.title: Should retailers use facial recognition at all?
value.excerpt: The FTC accused Rite Aid of misusing facial recognition technology - without informing customers or employees - which resulted in false positives. Learn more about their misuse here.

value.title: How video game tech, AI, and computer vision help decode animal pain and behavior
value.excerpt: Top neuroscience labs are adapting new and unexpected tools to gain a deeper understanding of how mice, and ultimately humans, react to different drug treatments.

value.excerpt: Set to launch its eCV series SoCs later in 2024, eYs3D is embracing its concept of "AI+" and expanding its offering from USB-based controllers to full-fledged, edge-based SoCs. value.title: Spying on Beavers From Space Could Help Save California
value.excerpt: A group of scientists taught an algorithm to spot beaver ponds in satellite imagery, which has the potential to help drought-ridden areas like California bounce back.

value.title: Rite Aid’s A.I. Facial Recognition Wrongly Tagged People of Color as Shoplifters
value.excerpt: Under the terms of a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission, the pharmacy chain will be barred from using the technology as a surveillance tool for five years.

value.title: FTC Crackdown on Rite Aid Over Facial Recognition Is a Lesson on Risks of AI
value.excerpt: The FTC handed Rite Aid a five-year ban on using facial recognition technology for surveillance.
